Today Mott Haven is still one of the poorest communities in the USA. Mott Haven contains the highest concentration of Puerto Ricans in NYC. New low income housing has been built or is in the process of being planned out and constructed. Many abandoned buildings and homes have been or are being renovated for low income residents and many subsidized townhouses have been built. Despite declines from their peaks during the crack and heroin epidemics violent crime is still a big problem in the community. Drug dealing, homelessness, failing schools and many other social problems associated with poverty continue to burden the community but work is slowly being done to improve the quality of life somewhat for those living in the community.
+
There are 3 historic districts in Mott Haven: Mott Haven, Mott Haven East and the Bertine Block. The historic districts preserve brick rowhouses of the Italiante, neo-Grecian and other styles. Some artists and professionals have been moving into lofts and historic brownstones in these areas, along with a small concentration of new restaurants and cafes. An Antiques District has grown along Bruckner Boulevard and Alexander Avenue, in sight of the old piano and other factories. Recently, the city has rezoned former commercial areas in and near Mott Haven for mixed-use and residential occupation, and additional abandoned commercial buildings are now in the process of being converted into residential lofts<ref>Hughes, C.J. "Bonfire of the Vanities No Longer".
